Description: Egyptian terracotta of a woman in Classical Greek style. Mould-made and hollow. White coating preserved on some areas of face. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with black core. Abundant fine gold and silver mica, common quartz, clay pellets, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Classical Greek style terracotta. Three similar pieces from Naukratis have different fabrics are in the British Museum (GR2011,5009.285, imported), Bristol Museum (H446.b, imported) and Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology (NA351 made in Egypt). These small fragments seem to be of a style seen on Classical Greek standing and seated female figurines of the early to mid 5th century BC from Rhodes, Attica and Cyrenaica (Higgins 1954, 111, 204, 220-8, 669-74, 1422).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.018) (Phase 1)
